context: (E)-β-ocimene is a component of many floral scents, and it is one of the most common of the monoterpenes that are emitted from leaves in response to damage by mechanical wounding or herbivores. It is a component of an induced volatile blend that is thought to protect plants by attracting natural enemies of herbivores, as either parasitoids or predators. Moreover, (E)-β-ocimene has a role in plant–plant interactions, in resistance to pathogens, and in tolerance to high temperatures. (E)-β-ocimene was also the predominant monoterpene released from tobacco plants inoculated with various strains of P. syringae  and its emission has been seen in peanut plants infected by the white mould S. rolsfii  . In addition, in Lima beans, exogenous (E)-β-ocimene treatment induced a set of genes involved in the plant defence responses. All these compounds were never detected in control plants while the oxygenate monoterpene linalool was emitted from both control and treated plants, although 24 h after MeJA exposure, it was no longer detected. The maximum increase of linalool was seen 48 h after the MeJA treatment.

llm_generation.summary: (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene, specifically (E)-β-ocimene, is identified as a prominent member of the monoterpenes class. It plays a crucial role in plant defense mechanisms, emitted in response to herbivore damage and pathogen infection. The context highlights its significance in attracting natural enemies of herbivores and inducing plant defense genes, underscoring its functional relevance as a monoterpene in ecological interactions.
